comments.commentBody: Does anyone believe there is an innocent explanation anymore?  It's simple what is happening.  The U.S. is being sold out for trump change.
Don't forget Hillary sold 20% of the US Uranium supply to Putin. How's that for companionship?
Trump isn't an equitable negotiator. He will cut off his own nose to spite your face.

Are there no persons of integrity in the GOP?  It is obvious that our country has been attacked by Russia. If our democracy is to survive, we must have a thorough, independent investigation along with the full disclosure of Trump's taxes. What are they so desperately hiding? We shall find out in time.

@Mark:

Sen. McCain and Sen. Graham have integrity, and they do frame issues beyond the dictates of narrow political partisanship. That fact alone makes them stand out in a party full of sellouts, partisan hacks, ideological cranks and spineless sycophants -- ciphers devoid of it. This is why their lives are in danger.

Should they take a crucial leading role in forcing the Senate to investigate the Putin regime's involvement in Trump's election campaign they do it at no small risk to their lives and families. They risk of being neutralized on Putin's orders by his people here. Dying suddenly, in unclear or mysterious circumstances. Or shot during an "attempted robbery". Or "taken ill" after being poisoned. They will join hundreds of Putin's critics and political enemies killed anywhere his agents could reach them.

Russians living here openly or covertly, agents in Russia's FSB working with or without diplomatic cover, will arrange it or do it themselves.

Trump, of course, will deny that anything of the sort had occurred, insisting that no connection between it, himself and his Kremlin master exists.

Never forget for a moment that we are at war with Russia.

The answer to your question is a resounding no.  Also, we will not find out in time or anytime.  As long as Republicans are in charge there will not be an "independent" investigation.  Remember elections have consequences and we now live in TrumpAmerica.

Has our country really "been attacked by Russia?" I detest Trump as much as anyone but I also don't buy efforts to push for a cold (or maybe hot) war with Russia. I don't hear anyone accusing Israel of "attacking us" but they have done more than the Russians to influence our leaders and our elections. There are good reasons to investigate international conflicts of interests withing this or any administration. This should include business as well as the influence of foreign governments whether Russian, Saudi, Israeli or Chinese. As for the focus on Russia we are seeing, it is vital that we separate actual harmful conflicting connections and influence from overblown narratives pushed to promote pretexts for a National Security State coup with dangerous implications. Journalist Paul Street writes of the danger of blindly repeating convention narratives:
http://www.truthdig.com/report/item/the_deep_states_hatred_of_trump_is_n...

Walker is a well financed Koch Bros lackey, who has hurt the downtrodden in his state, since he has held political office. He is arguing that the states should have the powers, and not the federal government.

Yup, Walker busted the unions in Wisconsin...So why isn't he working to kill the House bill sponsored by Congressmen Steve King and Joe Wilson to make right to work a federal law, since it should be regulated by the states.

Further, how come Walker didn't oppose federal legislation last year to preclude the labeling of gmos by the big food industry, and leave that to the states. The argument there was it would be too expensive by the food industry behemoths to do so for smaller jurisdictions.

Finally, this political giant, has been planning to run for Pres, next time around.

While in Madison a few years back I was walking up State Street toward the capital when I noticed to the right at the top of state street - directly across the street from the capitol (and stinking up the atmosphere around Myles' Teddywedgers!) - an office for Koch Industries. I thought at that time that it was a very convenient location for that office. I wonder how many other state capitol buildings have Koch offices immediately adjacent to them?
Wampum had deep cultural significance for northeast tribes over thousands of years. A clever clue and hardly insulting.

In the meanwhile, what is happening to Arizona public schools if all this money is pouring into the private ones?

We would assume they are being defunded, so the real poor kids, who attend public just hang in there in impoverished public school systems then.

So unfair, using innocent kids these days to support "Christians" - long way from Mother Theresa and her philosophies.

Yes, vouchers and charters divert money from the traditional public schools. Yes, this causes the poorest kids to suffer.
Yes, when I sent my children to private high school (although I still paid about $10K in property/school taxes), Dallas ISD lost my child's allotment of money.

But even if Christians band together to flood the public schools with their presence, thus returning millions of dollars to a district's coffers, I'm here to tell you that it won't matter. Dozens of my neighbors and I tried.

The creaking Titanic of regulations, bureaucrats, testing, more testing, directives to ignore discipline problems, constant teacher turnover due to regulations/bureaucrats/constant testing/discipline issues, etc will cause all of those kids to suffer, too. And the money? It will just be handed out to a fleet of adults who never interact with a child; it certainly won't be spent on Sp Ed services, reading interventionists, or school psychologists.

Almost all URBAN districts need to be dismantled. They are the DMVs of education; they are the Detroits of education. There is no saving them. They're too big, too entrenched, and completely unresponsive.

If power returns to the states, the smartest policy for a state is to be among the first to persuade unneeded workers, people with expensive medical conditions, or elderly people without retirement portfolios to move to other states. This is how the South handled its excess agricultural labor as cotton production was mechanized -- keep benefits low and call the newly unemployed lazy. States with generous benefits will be penalized by getting more of the needy.

After more than a few states adopt such policies, the policy will be less successful, and states will compete to make their policies among the most repulsive. This is just the invisible hand of the marketplace operating. For the invisible hand, excess people should suffer the same fate as any other item that is in excess. To keep them around when they are not needed is a violation of market rationality, and the invisible hand will tend to eliminate them by various mechanisms. This is why civilized countries put limits on market rationality.
And then the wealthier states will build walls, and get the poorer states to pay for them.
... which is why a loose confederal system does not work and a federal system with transfer payments acts as a balancing force, keeping the nation together..

"This is just the invisible hand of the marketplace operating."
The invisible hand needs a good sharp rap on the knuckles with a ruler.
Go figure. The Russians have done a better job of vetting their candidates for high positions in the U.S. government than the Republican Senate!

The only utility of keeping the spotlight on Sessions is that it keeps Trump's Russian connections at the front of the conversation. But, the risk is that we go down a rabbit hole and burn too much political capital with limited upside when there are other investigation streams that when explored have greater payoff potential.

There's that Fertilizer King, Dmitry, who seems to be in the same place as Trump much too frequently.

There's Deutsche Bank that has served Trump in many capacities from (creatively) raising capital to being his private banker. Isn't there any disgruntled ex-employee to talk to?

I'm also for Schiff's committee issuing a subpoena for Director Comey. This farce has gone on for way too long...

And I know that the R(ussian) NC is closing ranks to prevent an independent investigation into Trump - Russia ties. We should directly link every single Republican up for 2018 election (House and Senate) to this scandal. Any Republican member in Congress opposing an independent investigation must be tagged as an accomplice to an act of a hostile power against the country.

All we want is the truth. Not a cover-up.

All we want is the truth. Not a cover-up.

you can't handle the truth!
Yes!

As we predicted before the election, scandal will begot scandal will begot scandal will begot scandal into infinity with these Trump people.  We will now spend all of our time trying to untangle this mighty mess our new administration has created. This is time we might have spent helping those in need and creating a more efficient government.

Putin will _adore_ this!

A US Senator -- Al Franken no less! -- described the Russian Federation as "maybe the second or third biggest power in the world."

As different as Putin is from Trump (in some ways, they are polar opposites) they share some fundamental traits. They have a desperate needy hunger to be frequently told that they are Big Important Men, and to see gorgeous demonstrations of Respect and/or Fear. Most of all, they delight in the humiliation of their adversaries.

For more on this personality trait, see Mario Puzo's "The Godfather"

Yes, for sure, but Putin *believes* in his Big Important Man status. His self-esteem is rock solid. Trump is a case of arrested development. His behavior is so erratic because he is colossally insecure about whether he is actually Someone Important, and he's incapable of hiding his fear. That's why he has to bray and bellow so ceaselessly. You never see such embarrassing behavior from Putin.

What have we come to, when despite being a vicious murderer, the Russian president is far classier than our own.

Allen -- "Worry more about what Trump is hiding from the citizens of the USA than about catching the individuals helping us find out the facts."

I'll bet that is not what you said about what Hillary was hiding from the citizens of the USA, which is what started all of this, as it was hacked or leaked by Russians or insiders.

I'm waiting for the Christopher Steele dossier to be investigated and proven correct. Along with the current US Intelligence community investigations. Then we can say goodbye to Trumpistan forever. And make America great again.
Very soon, Lord willing, and the creek don't rise.
Parts of the dossier have already been confirmed.

Trump's Russian ties keep growing:
#1-Sessions, General Flynn, Carter Page lie under oath about Russian contacts
#2-US intelligence agencies confirm truth of elements contained in Russian dossier on Trump
#3-Add'l staff Roger Stone, son-in-law Kushner, Trump's lawyer have multiple Russian contacts; Trump's lawyer shows up at WH with a Russian-friendly Ukraine peace plan
#4-"The Curious World of Donald Trump’s Private Russian Connections" details how Russia funneled money to Trump through U.S.-based emigre retirees
#5- Trump Server Communicates With Russia reports Slate Magazine, 10/31/2016
#6-Putin ties to Exxon Chief Rex Tillerson to push $500B oil dev deal
#7-Russian-paid fake news bloggers release fake news stories critical of Clinton
#8-Wikileaks under Russians tutelage publish Democratic Party-hacked info to tip election
#9-17 U.S. intelligence agencies report U.S. election, hack dismissed by Trump
#10-Trump threatens other countries, long-time U.S. supporters, allies -- but praises, defends Putin
#11-Trump appoints Wilber Ross commerce secretary; Ross' Bank of Cypress has ties to long-time Putin ally Viktor Vekselberg & former vice-chairman Vladimir Strzhalkovsky, a former KGB agent with a close relationship to Putin. Russia invests in Bank. Deutsch Bank CE recruited by Ross. Deutsch largest Trump creditor.
#12--Trump campaign manager Manafort, paid $12+m to lobby for Russian-backed former Ukrainian president Viktor Yanukovych; changes Republican platform.

White House accused of blocking information on bank's Trump-Russia links
https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/27/commerce-nominee-wilbur-...

Russian contacts – what it means. Not just the friendly overtures one would hope.
https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2017/02/what-does-it-m...

There is no one who in seeing the suffering of a person in a film doesn't have the thought that had he been there, he would have helped the poor person. Yet, we are reluctant to act in real life. (other than inability to provide the help).
because we are not sure that we are facing a situation of real want rather than someone who is gaming the "system". Nevertheless, if you can, better to sin toward generosity. Which being to mind a short story by a Spanish author. It is about a bishop who walks to the cathedral every day and meets beggars. He never fails to give something and in doing so recommends: "Use it for your vices".

"White House accused of blocking information on bank's Trump-Russia links"
https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/27/commerce-nominee-wilbur-...
Article examines, in part, Secretary of Commerce Wilber Ross' role at the Bank of Cypress where he maintained contacts with long-time Putin ally and investor Viktor Vekselberg and Vladimir Strzhalkovsky, a former vice-chairman of Bank of Cyprus who is also a former KGB agent with a close relationship to Putin. Ross recruited Deutsch Bank CE Ackerman to the bank's board. Deutsch Bank is rumored to be Trump's larger creditor.

"The Curious World of Donald Trump’s Private Russian Connections"
http://www.the-american-interest.com/2016/12/19/the-curious-world-of-don...

Most of his nominees are on the record to destroy the agency that they are now picked to run. Anyone with a bit of common sense isn't going to put someone in charge of the firehouse when that person is calling for burning down the firehouse. Of course if the goal is to destroy the US government, then I suppose putting those people in charge will help that along.

"It is of great importance to set a resolution, not to be shaken, never to tell an untruth. There is no vice so mean, so pitiful, so contemptible; and he who permits himself to tell a lie once, finds it much easier to do it a second and third time, till at length it becomes habitual; he tells lies without attending to it, and truths without the world's believing him. This falsehood of the tongue leads to that of the heart, and in time depraves all its good dispositions."
-- Donald Trump on Jeff Sessions (overheard in the Fox & Friends studio)
(often erroneously attributed to Thomas Jefferson in a letter to Peter Carr)
Actually, the most pitiful thing is that Trump probably couldn’t even read this off a teleprompter.  And it doesn’t fit in a tweet.
Very good point. And your comments on "attributions" are hilarious and clever  Bravo

@Blue Moon, you must be talking about Obama who lied about his health care plan, " keep your doctor, keep your plan" not once but 28x in a wide variety of speeches and interviews. The more he repeated the lies the more easily the lies just rolled off his tongue. I could go on and on about Hillary and her lies.... in any event there has been no proof put forth that anyone colluded with the Russians. Just a bunch of Trump haters connecting dots to the outcome they desire.

Government by feeding frenzy.

I am heartily sick of it. I was sick of it in the Clinton years and I am sick of it now.

Every single politician who cares more about personal ambition, party affiliation, ideology, and sticking it to the opposition than about upholding the integrity of our system of government, putting the welfare of the country first, and representing their constituents honorably, should be fired.

It is time for the American people to get serious about placing people in office who deserve to be there, who are dedicatwd to serving their country, not their egos.

Yes, we must innvestigate, fully and fairly, charges of wrongdoing. But without rancor, and without glee. For we are becoming the thing that we profess to oppose, losing ourselves and our nation, in the process.

The said thing is "firing" these politicians is not that easy. The have to be impeached. That does for Congress-persons as well as Presidents.  And the people doing the impeaching would be people in Congress.  Clever, eh?
Maybe those remedies should be reviewed and changed while we are at it.  There is far too little accountability on the Hill.

Also add:
11. Social Security Reform Act of 2016 - which includes drastic cuts
12. Repeal on background gun purchase check rule that screened out people receiving special Social Security benefits (because mental problems made it impossible for them to work or even manage their own money).
13. Repealed regulation prohibiting coal companies from dumping their waste into streams.
14. Signed a bill repealing a rule that publicly traded oil, gas and mining companies had to disclose payments they make to foreign governments.
15. Rescinded the Parole in Place program for non-citizen immediate family members of active U.S. military personnel or veterans to apply for a US green card, without having to leave the country.
Perhaps the Russian-hacked RNC server(s) exposed secrets worth holding over the Republicans' heads.
